Overview

Automated testing of a web applications developed in ADF Faces requires knowledge of named DOM elements. In Java Server Faces, web pages are created from a composition of components. In the design time view, each component is assigned a unique ID. These ID's are represented at runtime in the browser HTML DOM as id attributes of nodes that correspond to the component and are called client ids. Components hide the markup needed to render itself in the browser. These DOM structures can be very complex and for good reason best hidden form the end user.

However, for the purpose of automated testing, the test writer needs to know more about the DOM structures of each component in order to facility automated testing from products like Selenium. Subparts of complex components are identified by subids. Component subids come in two varieties, internal and external. Internal component client ids are the default. These can be very cryptic as they represent the internal implementation details of the component. These ids can also be very brittle when used for testing as they may change to support enhancements as the framework evolves. Complex composite components such as the table and region use the internal component ids to implement stamping. Because this is an implementation detail, it could change from release to release. For this reason, the concept of component external ids exists.

External component ids, rich locators and its syntax

External component ids are simplified internal ids used at runtime for the sole purpose of building more robust automated testing. The external ids hide the internal implementation details of components so that tests can be created without specific knowledge of how component stamping is currently implemented by a particular component. External component ids by default are not turned on. You must explicitly turn on automation via a context parameter in the web deployment descriptor of your web application. There is a considerable performance cost for turning on automation therefore should only be used during testing.

Consider the following snippet from the WEB-INF/web.xml that turns on automation mode:

  <context-param>
    <description>
      This parameter notifies ADF Faces that test automation is being used.
      When enabled, this will cause the ids of components with testId
      attributes to be set to the value of the testId and the client component
      attribute of the component to be forced to true.

      TestId attribute is now deprecated; use the 'id' attribute instead.
    </description>
    <param-name>oracle.adf.view.rich.automation.ENABLED</param-name>
    <param-value>true</param-value>
  </context-param>

A rich locator is a means to use these external component ids with Selenium test framework. It has two parts, a scopeId and a subId. A rich locator will have the syntax "rich=scopeId#subId". scopeId part in the syntax represents the ADF Faces component to be located. For most ADF Faces components, scopeId will be same as its internal id, except in the case of stamping components like table. For stamped components the syntax of the locator will be containing stamp key in square brackets ([]). subId part (optional) is used to access any internal details of the component. Here are some sample usages:

  • rich=idInputText - represents rich locator for an af:inputText component
  • rich=idInputText#label - represents rich locator for the label an af:inputText component
  • rich=idInputText#content - represents rich locator for the content an af:inputText component
  • rich=idTable[1]:idInputText#content - represents rich locator for the content an af:inputText component inside af:table with stampKey = 1

For a comprehensive list of subId supported for ADF Faces components, see the Component SubIds Doc.

About adf-rich-automation test infrastructure

adf-richclient-automation exposes a set of utilities and a base class for writing Selenium WebDriver based tests. RichWebDriverTest class is the preferred base class for writing test cases which interact with ADF Faces pages. Any action method in this base class like click(), sendKeys(), clear(), contextClick() etc accepts a locator to locate the element on the ADF page on which the action has to be performed. The locator used here can use one of rich, id, xpath, css, name, tagName or link strategy. The choice of strategy for the locator can be specified using a prefix to the locator, eg: rich=, id=, css=, tagName= etc, but is optional. If no prefix is used, the locator will be assumed to be rich= locator. If there is no ADF component available with the rich locator, then it falls back on id=. More details on this is available in the javadocs for adf-richclient-automation. The test framework allows usage of different types of locators for flexibility. However, rich locators are the most preferred as it is the most stable locator strategy when it comes to ADF Faces components. All other strategy can potentially face a failure, when the internal HTML DOM structure of an ADF component changes.

WebDriver keeps updating (both remove and add) native event support for firefox with each release. For e.g: WebDriver 2.40 added native event support for FF27 and removed it for FF25. Tests can control the the native events setting for firefox, using system parameter enable.firefox.native.events. By default, firefox native events will be turned ON.

Test Automation for ADF Data Visualization Components

The ADF Data Visualization Components support test automation verification and interaction via Rich JavaScript component apis. In order to allow JavaScript components to be located via a testing tools, ADF Faces provides the ability to locate JavaScript component instances using a rich locator ( e.g. "rich=graph1" ). For test automation, once a component's Rich JavaScript component has been located, its javascript verification and interaction apis can be called to:

  • Verify component state - DOM for DVT components is private and should not be directly accessed for verification purposes (see public subIds documentation for DVT verification APIs)
  • Trigger actions via subIds
  • Record actions via subIds - Requires client side test tool integration / not provided via the ADF Faces Selenium User Extension
To support calling rich component apis via Selenium, the ADF Faces Selenium User Extension supports calling javascript apis on rich components using the following RichWebDriverTest apis:
  • Object getRichComponentProperty(String locator, String propertyName)
  • Map<String, Object> getRichComponentProperties(String locator, Set<String> properties)
  • Object callRichComponentFunction(String locator, String functionName, Object... args)
  • Object callRichComponentFunctionChain(String locator, String[] functionNames, Object[][] functionArgs)
Triggering actions

Legacy components like graph and gauge need to use the AdfFlashAutomation APIs to trigger actions despite now only rendering in HTML5. Supported action APIs are listed below.

  • AdfFlashAutomation AdfDvtGraph.getFlashAutomation()
  • AdfFlashAutomation AdfDvtGauge.getFlashAutomation()
  • void AdfFlashAutomation.click(String subid)
  • void AdfFlashAutomation.mouseOver(String subid)
  • void AdfFlashAutomation.mouseOut(String subid)
  • void AdfFlashAutomation.keyDown(String subid, Number keycode)
  • void AdfFlashAutomation.keyUp(String subid, Number keycode)
Recording actions

Many automated testing tools have the ability to record mouse / key actions that occur on DOM Elements. Typically, this works on DHTML components by the test tool receiving a DOM event with a target element and then recording the event using a persistent locator / identifier for the target element. Legacy DVT components Graph and Gauge support recording of actions via the following API that is used to fetch a subid for the object that a DOM event was triggered on: 

  // Returns the subId locator for the subcomponent targeted by the DOM Event.
  AdfFlashAutomation.getSubIdLocator(domEvent:Event):String
In order to playback an action on a component, component.getFlashAutomation().click(subid) can be used with the same subId that was recorded.
Test Automation for the Dialog Framework

In an effort to create an abstraction between the implementation details and what is required by automation test authors, a selenium extension API exists to test the dialog framework. This API should follow an action command that launches a dialog.

There are three ways to launch a dialog using the dialog framework:
  • ADFc called taskflow activity. This type of dialog can be an inline popup or browser window but will always be modal.
  • An action outcome prefixed with "dialog:" and with the command buttons useWindow set to "true". It can be an inline popup window or browser window and modal or modeless.
  • The dialog service API can be called from a lifecycle phase such as apply request values or invoke application. It can be an inline popup window or browser window and modal or modeless.

The same selenium API transparently handles dialogs launched as a browser window or dialogs open as inline popup dialogs embedded within an iframe.

The ADF Faces Selenium User Extension supports calling javascript apis on rich components using the following RichWebDriverTest apis:
  • DialogInfo waitForRichDialogLaunch(DialogLauncher launcher)
  • DialogInfo waitForRichChildDialogLaunch(DialogLauncher launcher, DialogInfo parentDialogInfo)
  • void waitForRichDialogReturn(DialogInfo dialogInfo)
  • DialogInfo selectRichDialog(DialogInfo dialogInfo)
  • DialogInfo waitForRichDialog(DialogLauncher launcher, long timeout)
  • DialogInfo waitForRichChildDialog(DialogLauncher launcher, DialogInfo parentDialogInfo, long timeout)

Automation Examples

The following are some sample selenium tests written using the ADF Faces rich locator API. You will find the interesting Selenium junit test fragments in bold. For a comprehensive list of component subIds for ADF Faces components, see the Component SubIds Doc.

Inline Popup Dialog Automation Example

<af:popup id="popupDialog" contentDelivery="lazyUncached">
  <af:dialog id="dialog" title="Test Dialog" affirmativeTextAndAccessKey="Y&eah"
             cancelTextAndAccessKey="&Oops" noTextAndAccessKey="N&ah"
             helpTopicId="TOPICID_ALL">
    <af:panelGroupLayout layout="vertical" id="pgl2">
      <af:inputText required="true" label="Required" id="it1"/>
      <af:showDetailHeader text="Details" disclosed="false"
                           id="sdh1">
        <af:panelGroupLayout layout="vertical" id="pgl3">
          <af:outputText value="All rights reserved." id="ot1"/>
          <af:outputText value="Subject to terms and conditions."
                         id="ot2"/>
          <af:outputText value="Not applicable on weekends."
                         id="ot3"/>
        </af:panelGroupLayout>
      </af:showDetailHeader>
    </af:panelGroupLayout>
  </af:dialog>
</af:popup>
<af:commandButton immediate="true" text="Show Dialog" id="cb1">
  <af:showPopupBehavior popupId="popupDialog"/>
</af:commandButton>
Selenium/ADF Faces code sample
        // load dialog demo page
        startupTest(); // use TestConfig to pass the test page paramters "components/dialog.jspx"

        // **** start test ok button ***

        // click command button to launch the dialog
        verifyTrue("message", isElementPresent("rich=dmoTpl:cb1"));
        click("rich=dmoTpl:cb1");

        // checking for popup.isPopupVisible()
        waitForRichPopupVisible("rich=dmoTpl:popupDialog");

        // check the dialog's title
        verifyTrue("message", isElementPresent("rich=dmoTpl:dialog#title"));
        String title = getElementText("rich=dmoTpl:dialog#title");
        verifyEquals("dialog title", "Test Dialog", title);

        // populate the requried input field
        verifyTrue("message", isElementPresent("rich=dmoTpl:it1"));
        sendKeys("rich=dmoTpl:it1#content", "zyzpdq");

        // click on the OK button
        verifyTrue("message", isElementPresent("rich=dmoTpl:dialog#ok_button"));
        click("rich=dmoTpl:dialog#ok_button");

        // custom fuction checking for !popup.isPopupVisible()
        waitForRichPopupHidden("rich=dmoTpl:popupDialog");

        // **** end test ok button ***

        // **** start test cancel button ***

        // click command button to launch the dialog
        verifyTrue("message", isElementPresent("rich=dmoTpl:cb1"));
        click("rich=dmoTpl:cb1");

        // custom fuction checking for popup.isPopupVisible()
        waitForRichPopupVisible("rich=dmoTpl:popupDialog");

        // click on the cancel button
        verifyTrue("message", isElementPresent("rich=dmoTpl:dialog#cancel_button"));
        click("rich=dmoTpl:dialog#cancel_button");

        // checking for !popup.isPopupVisible()
        waitForRichPopupHidden("rich=dmoTpl:popupDialog");

        // **** end test cancel button ***


Table Automation Example

<af:table rowSelection="multiple" columnSelection="multiple" columnBandingInterval="0" autoHeightRows="0"
            columnSelectionListener="#{fs.handleColumnSelection}"
            binding="#{editor.component}" var="test1" value="#{tableTestData}" id="table"
            summary="table data" rowBandingInterval="0">
  <af:column width="40" rowHeader="true" headerText="Number"
               id="c1">
    <af:outputText value="#{test1.no}" id="ot1"/>
  </af:column>
  <af:column displayIndex="3" headerText="Number" align="right" sortProperty="no"
               sortable="true" id="c2">
    <af:outputText value="#{test1.no}" id="ot2"/>
  </af:column>
  <af:column displayIndex="1" headerText="Name" sortProperty="name" sortable="true"
               id="c3">
    <af:panelGroupLayout id="pgl2">
      <af:image source="#{test1.icon}" inlineStyle="width:16px; height:14px;"
                  shortDesc="icon" id="i1"/>
      <af:outputText inlineStyle="margin-left:8px" value="#{test1.name}"
                       id="ot3"/>
    </af:panelGroupLayout>
  </af:column>
  <af:column headerText="Size of the file in Kilo Bytes" headerNoWrap="true"
               displayIndex="2" align="end" id="c4">
    <af:outputText value="#{test1.size}" id="ot4"/>
  </af:column>
</af:table>
Selenium/ADF Faces code sample
        // load table demo page
		    startupTest() // use TestConfig to pass the test page paramters "components/table.jspx"

        // **** start test table test ***

        // verify the table and colum are present
        verifyTrue("message", isElementPresent("rich=dmoTpl:table"));

        // verify value of 3rd row
        verifyTrue("message", isElementPresent("rich=dmoTpl:table[2]:ot1"));
        String value = getElementText("rich=dmoTpl:table[2]:ot1");
        verifyEquals("row 3 column1", "2", value);

        verifyTrue("message", isElementPresent("rich=dmoTpl:table[2]:ot3"));
        value = getElementText("rich=dmoTpl:table[2]:ot3");
        verifyEquals("row 3 column3", "admin.jar", value);

        verifyTrue("message", isElementPresent("rich=dmoTpl:table[2]:ot4"));
        value = getElementText("rich=dmoTpl:table[2]:ot4");
        verifyEquals("row 3 column4", "1 KB", value);

        // an example of using the 'disclosureID' subid to expand a row in table
        // expand the row at row index = 3 and verify the detail stamp content is present
        click("rich=dmoTpl:table#[3]disclosureID");
        verifyTrue("message", isElementPresent("rich=dmoTpl:table[2]:it1::content"));

        // an example of using the 'filter_field' subid to type value into a filter field
        doType("rich=dmoTpl:table:c1#filter_field", ">400");
        
        // for the filter facet (date filter fields etc) use the component in the facet
        isElementPresent("rich=dmoTpl:table:inputDate::content");

        // **** end test table test ***

        // **** start test tree/treeTable test ***

        // the tree/treeTable selenium APIs with internal client subid usage
        // are the same as table. See table demo above

        // **** end test tree/treetable test ***

        // **** start test tree/treeTable test ***

        // the tree/treeTable selenium APIs with external client subid usage are the same as table. See table demo above

        // an example of using the 'disclosureID' subid to disclose a tree node
        // expand the 4th child of the 2nd root node and verify that child content is present
        click("rich=dmoTpl:tree#[1][3]disclosureID");
        verifyTrue("message", isElementPresent("rich=dmoTpl:tree[26]:it1::content"));

        // **** end test tree/treetable test ***


Graph Automation Example

<dvt:barGraph value="#{graphTestData}" id="graph1" title="My Graph Title" y1AxisTitle="Sales" o1AxisTitle="Products" clickListener="#{clickListener.processClick}"/>
</dvt:barGraph>
Selenium/ADF Faces code sample
            // load graph page
            startupTest(); // use TestConfig to pass the test page paramters "graph.jspx"

            // **** start graph test ***

            // verify the graph is present
            verifyTrue("message", isElementPresent("rich=graph1"));

            // verify the graph title
            Object result = getRichComponentProperty("rich=graph1", "title"});
            verifyEquals("graph title", "My Graph Title", result);

            // verify the y1Axis title
            result = callRichComponentFunctionChain("rich=graph1", new String[]{"getY1Axis","getTitle"}, new Object[][]{{},{}});
            verifyEquals("graph y1Axis title", "Sales", result);

            // verify the o1Axis title
            result = callRichComponentFunctionChain("rich=graph1", new String[]{"getO1Axis","getTitle"}, new Object[][]{{},{}});
            verifyEquals("graph o1Axis title", "Products", result);

            // verify the value of the first data marker
            result = callRichComponentFunctionChain("rich=graph1", new String[]{"getDataMarker","getValueY"}, new Object[][]{{new Integer(0),new Integer(0)},{}});
            verifyEquals("data marker for group 0 and series 0", "65", result);

            // click on the first data marker in the graph to change graph data / trigger an application action
            callRichComponentFunctionChain("rich=graph1", new String[]{"getFlashAutomation","click"}, new Object[][]{{},{"data[0][0]"}});

            // wait for the new graph data to arrive
            waitForServer();

            // verify if a new data was rendered by checking if first data marker value is now 20.
            result = callRichComponentFunctionChain("rich=graph1", new String[]{"getDataMarker","getValueY"}, new Object[][]{{new Integer(0),new Integer(0)},{}});
            verifyEquals("data marker for group 0 and series 0", "20", result);

            result = callRichComponentFunctionChain("rich=graph1", new String[]{"getDataMarker","getText"}, new Object[][]{{new Integer(0),new Integer(0)},{}});

            // **** end graph test ***


Dialog Framework Automation Example

<af:document id="d1" ....
  <af:commandButton id="launchCommand" label="Show Dialog" action="dialog:show" useWindow="true"/>

		  click("rich=launchCommand");
		  // -- wait until the dialog is open and select the last open
		  DialogInfo dialogInfo = waitForRichDialog(timeout);
		  // -- dialog now selected; commands are now targeted at the selected dialog window
		  click("rich=cancelButton");
		  // -- or use the "page.dialogService external ID on the af:document component --
		  click("rich=d1#page.dialogService#cancelButton");
		  // -- waits until the dialog returns and selects the previous parent window
		  waitForRichDialogReturn(dialogInfo);
